translated: Jātaka
Book 41: Tesakuṇajātaka
Cūḷasutasoma Jātaka
I bid farewell to the town,
and to my friends and relatives;
Gray hair has grown on my head,
now I delight in going forth.”
“In an unsuitable place, how can you say this?
You have planted a dart in my heart, god!
You have seven hundred wives,
how will they be for you?”
“They will know about this,
and the young women will go to others too;
Aspiring to heaven,
therefore I will go forth.”
“It was hard for me, Sutasoma,
that I was your mother;
Though I lament,
you go forth without concern, god.

original: Dulladdhaṁ me āsi sutasoma,🔽Yaṁ taṁ ahaṁ vijāyissaṁ;
analyzed: dulladdham me āsi suta soma  yam tam aham vijāyissa
translated: It was hard for me, Sutasoma,🔽that I would give birth to you;
Though I lament,
you go forth without concern, god.”
“What is this practice called,

original: Sutasoma kā ca nāma pabbajjā;🔽Yaṁ no amhe jiṇṇe,
analyzed: sutasoma kā ca nāma pabbajjā  yam naḥ amhe jiṇṇe
translated: Sutasoma, and what is this going forth?🔽That you go forth without concern, god,
leaving us old people behind.”
“You have many sons,
young, not yet in the prime of life;

analyzed: mañjū te ipi tam a passantā
translated: Not seeing you, I think,
they will be overcome by suffering.”
“These sons of mine,
young and not yet reached maturity,
and all of you, gentle ones,
will perish after a long time.”
“Is your heart cut out,

original: Adu te karuṇā ca natthi amhesu;
analyzed: adu te karuṇā ca natthi amhesu
translated: do you have no compassion for us?
While we are crying out,
you go forth without concern, god.”

original: “Na ca mayhaṁ chinnaṁ hadayaṁ,🔽Atthi karuṇāpi mayhaṁ tumhesu;
analyzed: na ca chinnam  atthi karuṇā api mayham tumhesu
translated: “My heart is not cut out,🔽I have compassion for you,
but I am going forth,
hoping for heaven.”
“It was hard for me,

analyzed: suta soma yassa te aham bhariyā
translated: Sutasoma, that I was your wife,
while I am crying out,
you go forth without concern, god.
It was hard for me,

analyzed: suta soma yassa te aham bhariyā
translated: Sutasoma, that I was your wife,
while I am carrying a child in my womb,
you go forth without concern, god.
My womb is ripe,
I will give birth to the child in my womb,
don’t let me be a widowed woman,
and later see suffering.”
“Your womb is ripe,
“Come, Moon, now be born from my womb;
A son of incomparable beauty,
Then I will leave the home life.”
“Do not weep, Moon,
Do not grieve, you with eyes like a fawn in the forest;
Ascend the excellent palace,
I will go without any concern.”

original: “Ko taṁ amma kopesi,🔽Kiṁ rodasi pekkhasi ca maṁ bāḷhaṁ;
analyzed: kaḥ tam amma kopesi  kim rodasi pekkhasi ca mama bāḷha
translated: “Who has angered you, my dear,🔽Why do you weep and look at me so much?
Whom should I kill,

original: Ñātīnaṁ udikkhamānānaṁ”.🔽“Na hi so sakkā hantuṁ,
analyzed: ñātīnam udikkhamānāna  na hi saḥ sakkā hantu
translated: As my relatives look on?”
“He who has defeated me, dear father, cannot be killed;
My father, dear father, said to me,
I will go without any concern.”
“When I used to go out before,
To the pleasure park and to fight with tusked elephants;
Now that Sutasoma has gone forth,
What will I do now?”
“My mother is weeping,
And my elder brother, unwilling;
I would take you by the hand,

analyzed: na hi gacchasi na u akāmāna
translated: But you will not go because we are unwilling.”
“Rise up, nurse,
Enjoy this boy elsewhere;
Do not make an obstacle for me,
As I seek the heavenly state.”
“If I were to give him the sun and moon,
what would be the use to me?
Since Sutasoma has gone forth,
what will I do with him?”
“Your treasury is full,
your storehouses are overflowing,
the earth is conquered by you,
enjoy yourself, don’t go forth, Your Majesty.”
“My treasury is full,
my storehouses are overflowing,
the earth is conquered by me,
but I will go forth, abandoning it.”
“I have much wealth,
Your Majesty, I cannot even calculate it,
I will give it all to you,
enjoy yourself, don’t go forth, Your Majesty.”
“I know you have much wealth,
you are honored with family wealth,
but seeking the heavens,
I will go forth.
I am greatly dissatisfied,
displeasure has overcome me, Somadatta,
I have many obstacles,
today I will go forth.”
“This is what you desire,

analyzed: suta soma ajjā iva dāni tvam pabbaja
translated: Sutasoma, today you should go forth,
I will also go forth,

original: Na ussahe tayā vinā ahaṁ ṭhātuṁ”.
analyzed: na ussahe tayā vinā aham ṭhātu
translated: I cannot bear to live without you.”
“It is not possible to go forth,

original: Nagare na hi paccati janapade ca;
analyzed: nagare na hi paccati janapade ca
translated: In the city or in the countryside.
When Sutasoma has gone forth,
What will we do now?
I think this is like
A little water in a hoofprint.
In such a short life,
It is not the time to be negligent.
I think this is like
A little water in a hoofprint.
In such a short life,
The blind and ignorant are negligent.
They increase the realms of hell,
The animal realm, and the realm of hungry ghosts.
Bound by the fetters of craving,
They increase the realm of the asuras.”
“The dust storm is approaching,
Not far from the eastern palace.
I think our hair is being cut,
Of the famous King of Dhamma.”
“This is his palace,
Covered with golden flowers and garlands.
Here the king used to roam,
Surrounded by his harem.

The king has gone forth,
Sutasoma has given up this kingdom,
Wearing ochre robes,
He wanders alone like an elephant.”
“Do not remember the games of love you played before,
Or recall your laughter,
Do not let your desires destroy you,
For the beautiful city of Sudassana is delightful.

original: Mettacittañca bhāvetha,🔽Appamāṇaṁ divā ca ratto ca;
analyzed: metta cittañca bhāvetha  appamāṇam divā ca ratto ca
translated: Develop a mind of loving-kindness,🔽Boundless day and night;
Come to the city of the gods,
The dwelling of those who make merit.”🔽The Short Story of Sutasoma, the Fifth.
The Fortieth Chapter is finished.
The summary:
Suva, the Wise One, the Rose-Apple, and Kuṇḍalī,
The Varaka Maiden, and the Mallotus Story;
The most excellent, the Conch, the Beautiful One, and the One with a Nose,
Sutasoma, and the King of the Gods, the Excellent King.
